comment: I bought this as an upgrade from the 50" Amazon basics tripod I mistakenly bought, that was too small to really handle a dslr with a big lens.When the 60" arrived, it had a few wear marks and was missing the quick attach mount. I'm pretty sure I ordered it new, so I'm unsure why it looks like I got an unchecked return.

I have two sizes of AmszonBasics tripods and both of them far exceed all expectations I had.  I'm not an expert in tripods but the quality and the strength and steadiness make them appear to have cost five times what I paid for them.  I use the larger one to support a large brass catcher for my rifle and I use the smaller one for my spotting scope.I'm not a person to gush over products and I'm often disappointed with them but in this case these tripods should both cost much more than Amazon sells them for.

worst tripod I ever experienced. You can not pan without shaky jerking movements. so light a small breeze can knock it down. I didn't expect much from the price and I got exactly that. I used as a 2nd camera support for a lecture I shot. If I didn't have the other tripod I would have been in big trouble. There is some good.quick release plate works ok.

I brought it all the way to Alaska and wanted to shot the aurora but just found out it didn't function well!  So furatrated! The bolt used to adjust the angle didn't work. I throw the item away. Waste of money.

Purchased this tripod just 5 months ago. I used it pretty regularly and always treated it well. Started falling apart by month 4 and noe its almost not even usable. It takes a lot for me to give a 1 star review. Height adjustment knob broke off, and 2 of the leg locks are broken.

Seems well built enough and light weight except the left-right motion was very sticky and refused to move smoothly even with the adjustment knob way loose. I ended up taking the difficult to remove top round nut loose and found the metal pad jammed. I removed it and lubed with shaft with silicone grease and now it is smooth. No need to lock it anyway.The camera mount part goes sideways too but does not seat exactly level. This will get me by until I get a more expensive heavy duty tripod. I pulled 2 stars for sticky friction problem repairs. Has an awkward long handle and it is reasonably stable and handles a P900 well but don't ever leave the up/down handle loose or the camera falls back or forward!!!  The handle is in the way of your face when viewing through the view finder. It cranks up and down well. Received earlier than expected.

For the money, this is a great product! For around $20, I was expecting a basic, low quality product to get me by. All it had to do was hold my camera (Nikon D5000) in place and I would have been satisfied. To my surprise, there are features included with this tripod that are on $40+ tripods! Two different bubble levelers, one for the base and another for the camera, an independent crank riser for additional height, multiple tightening locations to keep your camera in place, and the ability to hold your camera in both landscape and portrait.Since receiving this tripod, I did a "test" where I installed my camera and left it alone for almost five days with the legs fully extended and positioning locations locked / secured. This tripod held its position without any trouble, easing my concerns about it falling over and damaging my camera.

I have purchase many AmazonBasics products in the past and was very satisfied with the quality of each of the items I received. The 60-inch lightweight tripod was an exception.  After returning the first tripod because the head couldn’t be secured in place, I received a replacement tripod with the exact same problem. For all you photography buffs. If you try to mount a simple Canon SLR camera equipped with a 1lb Sigma Art lens in front of it, you will notice right away that the camera will tend to tilt forward, regardless of how hard you tighten the plastic knob.I purchased this tripod in order to take night pictures of the Northern Light in Iceland. The AmazonBasic tripod was rendered useless to me when I realized that the tripod head couldn’t stay up right when my camera was mounted on it.

Portability: Like the carrying case for it. Everything is light weight and perfect to attach to my bag without the case as well.Structure: Light weight but sturdy enough to hold my camera. The ball swivel feet are great for rougher terrain or uneven surfaces.

I sell products on Etsy, and taking pictures of the products is the bane of my existence.  We had a smaller, 45" tripod that my husband bought when he bought his camera.  It was so short, and I had to bend so much, that I hated using it and would have a backache for days.  I would put off taking the pictures, and by extension listing the items, as long as I could.So I bought a taller tripod.  It's 60", and I'm 66" tall (5'6").  It is AMAZING, the difference.  I love the multiple spirit levels, all the adjustments, and the hot swap plate especially.  It makes it so much easier to move the camera from the tripod in the living room, where I take the pictures, to the computer in the office, where I edit the pictures.

Finally used this tripod for the first time after having it for a year. We took it to Iceland and thank god we did because the aurora borealis appeared and there is no way we could have gotten photographs of it without a tripod. I can't have been more happy that I packed this tripod when I almost took it out of my luggage.The price is so cheap for a tripod in general. The build quality is great. It's sturdy. Even in the Iceland wind the tripod was able to stand its ground.

The package comes with a tripod bag and one Tripod made of hard plastic and aluminium. The tripod itself comes with 2 levels one on top of the legs and the other on the head.I liked the first tripod so much that I bought another one. I am still looking for one more tripod and for the price this is a top runner.

I absolutely LOVE this tripod. I have no clue how such a versatile tripod can go for so low...but hey just one more reason to LOVE Amazon.com!!As you can see I have no arms so I need a tripod that is lightweight but full on perks...this tripod is EVERYTHING I hoped for & then some!!!!

Bottom line: This is a decent tripod for the money, but it's not great.  If you can afford a better tripod, don't bother with this.This has some really solid components.  The legs themselves are pretty solid and have a great finish. The extensions pull out really nicely and stay in place perfectly.  The feet have little ball joints on the ends so you're always pretty stable regardless of what the ground is like.

As an "Intermediate" Photographer, testing the waters in professional/paid photography, I love this tripod! I do mostly nature, street, and portait shots, but I do occasionally do events and sports.  This tripod is great for all of that! It allows me to get a slow enough ShutterSpeed, whether I'm in a lower lighting situation such as a party & don't want to crank up my ISO, or I am doing a landscape shot, and want very creamy, soft, movement. The tripod is very inexpensive- who wants to pay + for brands??? Very lightweight. Easy to transport (comes with a bag). It has so many features! Definitely recomend. I will let you guys know if my opinion on the tripod changes.

I agonized for so long about getting a tripod for my Sony A6000, looking at pricey Manfrottos and the like, totally uncertain about what was best for my amateur video needs. Luckily I stumbled upon a photography review website that explained in lucid English that this simple $20/$25 tripod was basically all one would ever need for shooting in the home, on the beach, at graduation ceremonies, or in other non-demanding environments. They were 100% correct, and I pass this enthusiastic review along to anyone else who might be wondering whether they need the $250 carbon-filament Zomeii or the $500 Manfrotto just to get some video of their cat wandering around the apartment. This tripod is exceptionally stable, easy to lengthen/shorten, and has a super-easy detachable head thingy that, with the flick of a switch, can free your camera for hand-held shooting or for replacing the battery/memory card. I’m sure there are reasons why someone might want a super-high-end ultra-expensive tripod, but unless you have a heavy camera or the need to shoot in mountainous war-zones, I think this tripod is the rare example of a solution that’s not too good to be true. If you just want something to plop your light mirrorless camera on and shoot, this is a fantastic buy.

Haven't had time to learn about pro-tripods and decided to try this entry level thing. All I can say - it proves the name 'Basics'. It's OK for the price if you need to take a couple of family photos, not moreCons:

For less than $25, I got a decent tripod that's reasonably stable, with several nice features.  Each leg has two extensions that will lock at any point along their lengths.  Having  used it only twice at the range, I can't say if the leg locks will continue to hold firm, but for now, the friction is good and the platform is quite stable at any height I can conceive of needing.  As Range Safety Officer, while watching things pretty close, I can also spot for several shooters at a time, sometimes for five hours at a stretch, and I need to stay comfortable.  My spotting scope has an angled eyepiece, so I look down into it -- the tripod can be shorter than I'd need for a straight eyepiece.  I'm 5'10", and with the legs fully extended I only need to crank up the height adjustment two or three inches to be able to use the scope without bending over at all.  This tripod would be equally comfortable for a person who was 6'5" or more.In addition to the usual crank-up height adjustment, There are three "attitude" adjustments:  a protruding handle lets you swing the scope (or camera) vertically;  a knob lets you pan the scope/camera horizontally;  and a small "wing-nut" lets you tilt the scope/camera 90°, but ONLY TO THE RIGHT.  That seemed like a problem at first -- when shooting at a bench, I like the scope to be to the right of the bench, with the angled eyepiece tilted LEFT toward me.  If you'll check my photos, you'll see that I just reversed the scope (it'll mount either way), and tilted it left.

I bought this about 2 years ago, when just starting out on my photography journey, because it was the cheapest one I could find, figuring I'd upgrade to a nicer one eventually. In that time, I've used it a LOT, and when I'm not using it, I leave it in my car, so I always have it when I need it. It gets bumped around, things stacked on top of it, etc, and it's still just as sturdy as the day I bought it. It is an inexpensive tripod, so it's not as sturdy or smooth as some of the more expensive ones, and the legs are fixed, so you can't configure it in the same way as you can with a tripod that has independent legs, but that's rarely been an issue for me. And it really is a whole lot lighter than some of those nicer tripods. I can take this one hiking without a second thought, but I'd hesitate to take some of the more expensive tripods with their fancy heads. There's a whole lot of bang for your buck with this little thing, and I would recommend it to anyone who just needs a simple tripod for their hobby.

It's really not bad, considering the price.  But it has some fatal flaws:- there is too much friction in the plastic-on-plastic joints, which makes the up/down and left/right swivel actions very difficult to fine-tune

It's kind of flimsy in the field but lightweight enough to do the job when all you need is stabilization, such as shooting panoramas or even timelapse "selfies" to document a work procedure in stills or video unattended. Two of the rivet-like pins came loose after only a couple of weeks, but they can be replaced with #4-40 bolts if you use aircraft style safety nuts to keep from losing those, too. I'd get a heavier tripod for where rock-solid stability is required due to wind loading or similar things that would shake a camera, or with a longer lens than about 250mm. It jiggles too much in the slightest breeze for time exposures through a telephoto lens, but it gives nice night exposures with shorter lenses if shielded from wind.Good for a lightweight tripod to carry where a high dollar heavy one would be too cumbersome, where if you break or bend it, it's not a huge loss to replace it. It's probably excellent with a lighter weight camera and lens assembly. With the legs fully retracted, it's great on a workbench to photograph repair or assembly procedures when writing a manual. The legs have enough different extension capability to level and stabilize the camera in rugged mountainous terrain to get those special shots that might be impossible to do handheld. Combined with the remote control wireless or wired shutter triggers, you can shoot pro quality scenes on a very low end budget.

I just got this product today, 6/12/17. First impressions I'm very pleased at the quality. I've tested and used all the features and found them to be rock solid. Now something I am surprised at is how many people I saw damage their product with the screw for the camera. I think people are twisting the camera instead of the screw. The screw isn't stationary it's on a loose track and you twist it from the inside to tighten the camera down. YOU DO NOT TWIST THE CAMERA.  I was wondering before I bought why I saw so many damaged devices. I was actually nervous to buy it. I recommend anyone with basic understanding to buy this. It's an amazing product, don't let misguided users effect your decision.Update: It's October 20th, this stand is still going strong. Not a single feature has been damaged. Moderate to heavy use.

When I first saw this tripod I thought It'd be a great solution for long exposure night photography in the city that I work on. Nothing too complex or requiring any extra durability or extreme weather condition usage.Upon first night of using this I loved it and the ability to adjust height with not only the adjustable locking latches (3 on each leg), but also the crankarm for additional height. That first night I did experience that while carrying it in the travel bag it comes with, the zipper to the bag came off as well as the strap and was no longer able to use it. Wasn't too much of an issue because I could still carry the tripod in my hand. The bag seemed to be made of cheap material. No huge loss though.

The last time I bought an inexpensive tripod was probably around 2002. I thought this one would be similar: it was the same price, after all. Not really: it is much lighter, and not as robust. For example, the way the feet are attached is simply a press fit. Somehow I managed to lose one in the first two weeks.It functions OK. It does what it says it does.  But if you are going to use a tripod with any kind of regularity, or travel with it to any extent, I would suggest spending even a little bit more money and getting a more robust tripod.

I bought this to replace a clumsy old tripod that an elderly uncle gave to our grandson with a nice, tough little spotting scope.  Mounting and manipulating the spotting scope was frustrating for him, so I went looking for a quick-connect hookup to upgrade the old tripod.  It was actually cheaper to buy this whole tripod, which has a quick connect adapter.It's not tough construction (like the old tripod) but is easy to use, and should last until it's clear whether grandson will have long term interest that will justify a higher quality (more expensive) tripod.  I did buy the "insurance" that was offered at time of purchase, which I seldom do.  In this case, I think that might be a good decision.

UPDATE:  I'm decreasing my rating on this tripod from four stars to two, because it is not durable at all.  In addition to the plastic locking tab that broke off early on (see below), the quick release plate that attaches to the camera body cracked, and was no longer fastening securely to the camera.  I got a warranty replacement tripod from Amazon pretty quickly, which was nice.  However, one of the bolts on the center post slide broke within about a week, and has rendered the replacement tripod completely useless.  The tripod functions fairly well for hobby photography, but at this point, I have to say that the durability is terrible.  I use a tripod fairly often, and so I'm just going to do some research, spend more money, and get myself a much higher quality option.  I recommend you do the same.For the money, this is an excellent tripod. Lots of functions and capabilities, with numerous adjustments that can be made. The two levels are a nice touch. I would give five stars but one of the plastic tabs on one of the legs broke off, so that leg is now a real pain to adjust.

This thing is a real piece of junk.  I bought it solely for using with a small laser level that weighs way less than most any camera.  I assumed any tripod would be able to handle that, as it should.  The adjustment knob for the tilt can't get tight enough to hold it sturdy even when it's wrenched all the way down.  Maybe I received a defective one.  I initiated a return but forgot to drop it in the mail and now it's outside of the return window.  Absolute waste of money, not useful for anything and too large for a paperweight.  I wonder how many of these are in the landfill already.

I've had it for over a year and it works superwell. Good for the price. It is stable and can handle my camera, Canon EOS 7D with a mic on. Easy adjustable and easy to carry around as it is light-weight. It is smooth with horizontal pans for videos. Id be a little carefull with it if pointing camera straight up or straight down, particularly if your camera is heavy, just in case, but i have never had an issue. I have two, and have had no issue with either one. Ive used them on uneven surfaces, outside and for photo and film and it works absolutely great!

Overall I say this little tripod is a great deal! I am sure you can get something better, but at the PRICE it has worked well for us. We have had it now for two years and it is in great shape still. Extremely light weight and, although it might not be the most compact, I still think it is pretty compact in general. We've had our car packed to the brim and have always still found a place to slide this in. Easy to use and perfect if your looking for something to allow you to point and click. A good, basic, tripod.

The good, For the price it is a decent tripod. It is fairly light weight. It is a good basic tripod for still pictures. It is cheap enough if something happens to it you will not mind tossing it out. I would not recommend it for video cameras if you plan to use it for panning across an area because of the friction jerkiness. When panning, at it's lowest friction setting the movement is jerky and not smooth as is found with better tripods. The bad, It took three tries to get a good tripod. The first one purchased through Amazon Warehouse as new, had a broken quick release plate, returned it. Second unit again purchased through Amazon Warehouse, again advertised as new, was missing the quick release plate!!!! Third try, paid the full price, perfect!
This is a sturdy tripod that is feature rich and easy to use with only a few flaws:Sturdy:

After 4 months of light use, one of the legs already has issues.  The thing won't close around the leg and so that leg is always a bit off.Before this issue, it worked fine but issue with the leg started almost immediately after receiving it but finally became a bigger issue now.

When you stream like I do, efficiency, functionality and ease of use are pretty important when using products.  For a LONG time I was quite literally using a small table with books and had my webcam on that.  It was annoying and stupid looking and... well... annoying.I had been eyeing this tripod for a while and decided to just go for it.  It's amazing, awesome, spectacular.  It holds my webcam in place, and still allows me to switch up the settings on the tripod without having to worry about everything else moving too ie; there are a lot of different working parts and while they all work together, they work together on their own.

This is supposed to support up to 6 lbs.  I bought my daughter a table top telescope that can be removed from the original stand and mounted on a tripod.  The telescope weighs 3 lbs.  unfortunately it is very difficult to make fine adjustments to positioning on this tripod.  when ever I would lock in the vertical adjustment it would then drop down a little making it almost impossible to point the telescope.  I tried to tighten up the screw a little more and then it just broke so you couldn't use it any more.  Thankfully Amazon makes returns easy these days.  Took it to Kohl's and dropped it off and even got a 25% off coupon to use so there was something good to come of it.

Had previously bought a cheap tripod for my cellphone (as I don't even own a straight up camera). Worked ok but was a bit flimsy and not quite high enough. Saw this one and it looked a lot more sturdy so I decided to get it. To use this with my cellphone, I also had to buy a separate adapter to mate the cellphone to this tripod. Got both parts at the same time and tried everything out with my cellphone. Compared to my other tripod, this one is a rock. Holds my phone steady so making videos with it is pretty easy. Has all the adjustments I need to put the cellphone in any position I want in either landscape or portrait mode. Goes about a foot higher than my other one. The only knock I can give to this tripod is the swivel from side to side was way too tight even with adjustment all the way loose. It took both hands to turn from side to side cause you had to hold the tripod steady with one hand cause the tripod would move as you turned. Took me awhile to keep turning it around and around (like about 500 times) for it to loosen up where I could use it with one hand. Took off a star for that but other than that, this tripod is working very well for me. I plan on basically using this in the house or outside in the backyard and this will last me forever. It's not a professional tripod but I'm not a professional so it's fine. This tripod does everything I need it too. Can't beat the price either.

The reviews on this product is a little suspect.  Without the camera the tilt function is abnormally loose. It can not tighten. Very cheaply made. I am too nervous to put anything on long. I may try to use it for one of my monitors or lights but it is certainly something that I will not recommend.

We got our grandson a Celestron Landscout Spotting Scope, which he loves for night sky viewing. (Much better option than a low end kid telescope.) The Scope comes with a nice tabletop tripod, but that doesn't help if you're standing at the end of the driveway at night. This tripod was the perfect complement to that scope.As expected, the scope mounted without difficulty. The scope weighs in at over a pound, but that was no challenge for this tripod. Adjustments were logical and could easily be made by the kid. Loosening the mount, moving the scope around, and retightening were not a problem. Mechanism wasn't too tight. Legs weren't a problem. Stability was quite good. The carry case is handy. Adjustable height made the tripod very kid friendly.

This thing is awesome.  Low cost, sturdy enough for light weight items, easy to use, great features.  Details:Our uses: I used it to hold a laser level while redoing our living room subfloor.  This has a 2 way bubble level mounted in the lower frame, and a crank to raise & lower it - really made laser setup a breeze.  I can pan horizontally with almost no vertical shift.  Now my wife uses it to hold her phone as a webcam for Zoom meetings - nice and stable.

I had high hopes for this even though it's a really inexpensive tripod. I saw all the positive reviews and decided to buy one. Unfortunately, I'm reminded of the old adage, "Buy once, cry once."I bought it to use with a spotting scope and it is well within the tripod's weight rating. As soon as I tried to lock my spotting scope down, I noticed the head sagged so much, I could barely see my target 125 yards away. Basically, I had to put the top of my viewing area at the bottom of a 36 inch target to get it to center-up once I tightened everything down. I was really disappointed in that, and I'll be returning it. I'll just suck it up and drop the cash on a more expensive tripod.

Upon opening the box, I heard a rattle. A little bit concerned, I pulled out the tripod bag and unzipped it to find the tripod inside a plastic bag within the carrying bag. Upon turning it upside down to slide the tripod out, a washer, a nut, and a long black handle fell out of the bag along with the tripod. I looked for instructions. Not finding any, I had to look up the tripod picture here on Amazon to see what it was supposed to look like. Well.. the long black handle is supposed to be attached (and not come off) and is used for panning and tilting the camera while it is mounted to the tripod. When I tried to screw mine back in, it just falls back out.. it is like the screw is stripped or something. I am returning it and will spend money on something sturdier and better made. I have an expensive camera, and I don't want the camera to fall off and get damaged due to a cheap tripod that could easily break. Disappointed.

Great product so far. I own two businesses and I use social media as my marketing/branding platforms and I’ve used at least 5 other tripod before this one for business.Figuring out what works and doesn’t work, what I need and what I don’t want, these have been learnt through my experience.

I had this replaced after the first one didn't work out because one of the hinges would not tighten all the way no matter how had I twisted the knob. I wasn't able to stabilize the camera as it would just loosen and tip lens first downwards.  The replacement I was sent did the same exact thing.

The tripod that we had was quite a few years old, which we got as part of a camera kit. During a recent photo shoot one of the legs came off and we decided that it was time to find a replacement. We came across this tripod while searching and thought it should be decent based on the number of stars.This tripod is put together well, with sturdy legs, connectors and 2 levels. The legs are easy to extend and feature feet that can turn to most surfaces. The camera mount stem can easily be raised and lowered, using the crank, and tightened in place, by tightening the round fastener just above the top of the legs. There is also a fastener at the base of the main cylinder to lock the legs into their extended position, just above the hook for a weight. The overall height of this tripod with a DSLR attached to it when fully extended is just a little too much for someone that is 6’2” while standing up straight and needs to be lowered just a little bit. Basically, this should work for just about everyone, in regards to the height. The attached handle makes it easier to manipulate the tripod without any fear of pinching your skin in the process of setting up or taking it down. The included carrying case makes it convenient to store and transport, keeping it clean while not in use.

I'm past the window when I can get technical support or a replacement, and yet, I've barely used it in the time I've had it and it already broke. The little handle that you use to screw the quick release plate into the camera or iphone stand completely came apart and now a major part of this tripod doesn't work. Really disappointed. It works fine otherwise. It's very light, so in some cases that's great, in others it's not because you loose some stability. The levers and whatnot work fine, but they're clearly low quality. Everything is just a bit "eh."

For a simple tripod this is the best tripod we've used.  The tripod is sturdy and offers intuitive simplicity even for a novice photographer.  We use this mostly for family photo shoots.  All of the knobs and grips tighten and snap into place accordingly.  We've had this tripod for a few months now and we use it at least once a week and everything still works like the day we bought it. The telescoping legs aren't flimsy and slide in and out with ease. We've had issues in the past with the swivels and knobs loosening over time, or aluminum legs bending easily but so far this one has held up better than others. The bag is pretty standard but it fits the tripod accordingly, and is sturdy enough to be lugged around in the back of our car for the past few months without tearing.  There are obviously better and more expensive tripods available that have more features and perhaps a better build quality, but overall if you're not doing any upper echelon level photograph (or even if you are) I'd recommend this tripod based on price point and build quality.  You won't find a better bargain for a quality tripod than this one.

It didn't take a lot of time after receiving this, my first tripod, to decide that mounting a camera on a tripod opens up many new abilities when taking snapshots as well as when recording video. It's that third arm you need to keep everything pointed correctly. This tripod in unison with a remote shutter control has made everything much easier and it's showing better results. It's a natural for providing a solid positioning for vloggers when facing and speaking into their cameras.This inexpensive plastic tripod should not be quickly written off as some would do. It provides a huge amount of service for its meager price, for example when multi cameras are being used at different angles. Indeed it mimics everything an expensive tripod does, but this one works perfectly under a light workload, freeing up the more versatile equipment for better use when it is needed elsewhere.

I just got into DSLR photography and everyone advises you to get an expensive tripod. Personally I think that's a load of crap. When it comes down to it a tripod is a tripod and this is a great buy. With 2 separate leveling bubbles to level the stand and a decent swivel this tripod is a steal for $20. I'm 6'1" and when fully extended this tripod brings the viewfinder on my Nikon D5100 at almost exactly eye-level so it works good for me. No this isn't going to be the strongest most sturdy tripod you'll ever find but personally I dont throw my tripod into rocks or try to tackle it so it works just fine for me. The legs extend effortlessly and the locks on the legs seem to be of decent quality as I haven't had them slip or sink down at all.Also comes with a nice handle for moving it around while you're shooting. The top extension does drop a little if it's not tightened right away if your camera is heavy or you're using a heavy lens. But that's not really a big issue for me as I crank it up and just tighten it right away. If you're super picky this might be a problem for you but in all reality it's no big deal. The feet of the tripod have nice pivots to get an even stance when on the ground.

For the cost, which was a little over $23 at the time I got it, this is a good tripod.  It isn't great, but it will get the job done for most users I think.  I've been a big fan of AmazonBasics products over the years, and this is the first one that I sort of questioned when I first started messing with it.The plastic feels like it could be a little weak at places like the clips and knobs.  Nothing has broken yet, in the limited use I have given it, but I am being very careful as I adjust things.  But so far everything has worked how I'd expect.  The quick-release plate is very easy to take on and off, and seems firm so far.  I am using a small Handycam, which isn't very heavy.  I have not tried it with my wife's DSLR, which would be much heavier with a big lens on it.  We'll see.

I love this tripod. I am a film maker and I use really robust tripods on a daily basis. This is not that, but it is not advertised as that. It is a very basic light weight phone rig tripod and it is really amazing considering what it is. The price is right and I have been using it for my zoom meetings and teaching my online ZOOM class. It has a lot of great adjustments on it as well as a bullseye level on the bottom of the head. It has worked flawlessly for me over the past 3 months! Love it. If it broke tomorrow I would buy another one.  Anyone who has an issue with it or doesnt like it is most likely expecting a 12 hundred dollar tripod for 23 bucks!! Good luck. I use an I-Phone 11 with a handle bar frame and external shotgun mic. that screws right in to the 1/4 screw on the head.

I purchased this tripod over 2 1/2 years ago, and am personally impressed at how well it has held up. I have never used a "professional" grade tripod, and therefore cannot compare it to brands like Manfrotto. However, I can speak to its functionality from a beginning photographer standpoint. The only thing that this tripod can't properly execute, is pan shots for video. For that, you would need a tripod with a fluid head. For typical photography, this tripod has served me through many shots of running rivers and waterfalls, portrait photography, and was invaluable when I photographed the solar eclipse last year. To also attest to this product, would be the support I received from Amazon. A couple of months ago, I began to have issues with one of the legs no longer locking properly. I contacted Amazon to see if there was some way to fix this, and they sent me a brand new tripod. I have never regretted purchasing this tripod.

It came Broken and I had it shipped to Trinidad 🇹🇹 for an event I needed it for 😢😢😢😢 . To send it back to the States then wait for a new one  too expensive and I didnt have enough time !!! So heart broken ... whyyyyyy whyyyyyy !!!!!The actual product is wonderful made , nice carry bag . This hurts sooo badly 😢😢

This tripod is exactly what I was looking for. It is definitely light but not so much that it feels like cheap crap . It just wont kill your shoulders/arms carrying it places.I really love the added in levelers and how much the legs and neck for the tripod can extend. Also the carrying bag is a really nice addition so I can keep the tripod stored and protected well enough when I'm not using it.

This looks like a solid tripod at a great price. Unfortunately, it doesn't deliver. It is so light that it doesn't do much to stabilize the camera or scope mounted on it. I bought this to mount a spotting scope to see bullet holes at the shooting range. However, the tripod would shake so much in the slightest breeze that I couldn't see the target clearly. Even a strong hand on top of the scope didn't stabilize it. The tripod does have a hook on the bottom of the column, and I'm sure if I hung a bag of rocks on the hook that would help. But, that's a bigger hassle than just using a heavier tripod.This tripod is good for selfies and that's about it.

After reading some of the negative reviews saying that its just a flimsy plastic stand, I was pleasantly surprised after spending some time setting it up this afternoon. I found that it has some good features and it working for my portrait photo project. Theres many ways to adjust and tweak the stand until you get it right and it is very lightweight. I dont think its the best one best on the price point and that probably does reflect the quality overall, but i like it. Its basic and yet sturdy and cheap enough for beginners and gets the job done. Do recommend if you're not looking for anything extremely professional .

I returned this mainly because the motion was nowhere near fluid.  Especially panning.  You could not pan smoothly because it would bind.  Since my main application was taking video, this was unacceptable.  Trying to make MINOR adjustments to panning were difficult because it would fight you trying and then when it did give, you'd go too far.  If I was stuck with this tripod I maybe would have soaked the head in WD40 or something to try to loosen it up, but it wasn't worth the effort.  It IS a cheap tripod, I know that, and it checks a lot of the boxes when it comes to tripod requirements.  If you just need something to hold your camera and you don't think you'll be particular about where your camera is pointing...then maybe this is your tripod.

First things first! The price of this tripod is absolutely a winner here in my book. Any beginner photographer is going to need a tripod for either long exposures or time-lapse and if you do any video work it will help to keep the camera stable. Here are some other Pros for the Tripod.1. The Build

I loved this tripod and used it heavily for long exposures all around my city for a couple weeks. Then one of the lower black latches that holds one of the legs broke off and I've had to fidget with it since to make sure it's stable, though this may also be due to all the dirt and bangs its been exposed to over a relatively short time.That said, I still find this an exceptional value. I was up on a hill in high wind with this and it stayed perfectly steady with no stabilizer hooked to the bottom. It has 2 levels, a 360 level for the stand itself and a level to judge the mounting base by. Multiple levers and knobs which control or stabilize vertical and horizontal panning. Sleek design. Lightweight for its size and overall an incredible value. I didn't hesitate to buy another one at this cheap price to meet me ahead at the destination when I left for a winter trip. It ended up being a great tripod in the snow as well!

I purchased this tripod to hold a spotting scope at shooting matches and practice at the rifle range. I'm honestly impressed, especially with the price and simple features. I've seen tripods at sporting good stores that easily cost twice as much and are exactly the same thing.The tripod folds up and is stored neatly in an included case. The case is fine for transport and carrying around, but if you're flying on a plane or transporting it somewhere it might get dropped or have other items dropped on it, I'd say get something more substantial. A little waterproofing and the bag should be just fine outdoors in the rain.

I bought this for a gift.  I had ample time to test it before I gave it away.I consider this to be a starter tripod for someone new to photography to see if they would want a better tripod.  Good tripods are expensive.  Before buying an expenisve tripod, I wanted to see if the person to whom I gifted this item would even use a triopod.

This is my second purchase of this tripod.  I really like them but the clamps that hold the sliding legs fail too frequently.  So it would be a five star rating, but crappy engineering or materials result in failure after awhile.  I use these about 3 times a week to record videos of community events.  So, seek a better quality tripod, or bite the bullet, use it, and prepare to have to purchase a replacement in 1-2 years.  I think they are using substandard plastic that doesn't hold up long in the clamps.

Great tripods. Unless you have a giant multi pound TV new crew camera, these will work for most other needs.The build quality is there. The legs are sturdy. The plastic parts are thick and strong feeling. There is nothing new in this unit's design. I had something very similar (but less sturdy feeling) 25 years ago. Classic design built well with a good price.

The best 'budget' level Tripod available: fairly rugged, and has proved useful for both camera, webcam, and VR use.The mounting plate system is easy to use, though if you're like me, You'll probably want to pick up extra mounts for the rest of your devices you plan to mount to it.

A camera tripod has been on my Amazon wish list basically ever since I bought my fancy camera back in December 2014.  But for some reason I’ve just kept it there.  I’ve been worried about getting a cheap one and it breaking my camera or something.I don’t know people, I am not a camera savvy gal- I’m strictly a wannabe in this area.  I’m researching a ton and learning a lot though; that counts for something, right?

Aside from being taller, this tripod is of *much* better construction quality than its 50" smaller sibling, while still remaining lightweight. I'm 6'1" and this tripod works great for me when expanded to its full height with my D3400 mounted on it. It's plenty sturdy to hold the D3400 and keep it steady in more or less whatever position you want. I haven't had any problems with it slipping in any of its axes that I can recall. I used it extensively during a trip to Hawaii and Asia and also some on a trip to Yellowstone and it has held up fine, so far.While it's plenty sturdy, the aluminum construction also makes it light. It's easy to carry comfortably over my shoulder with the included case. Carrying it and my camera bag around was no problem at all, even while doing some light hiking on a few occasions.

Great for beginners or folks that just need something simple to hold their camera steady. I use my smartphone for filming and this is great at keeping it steady without breaking the bank. And at 60" tall, it's about the right height for matching up with my eye level. Check out my video review.

I picked this up to shoot videos with a cell phone.  It is a perfectly good tripod - perhaps a little too lightweight for some applications but it works well for what we needed.  It pairs very well with a cell phone holder that is also available on Amazon!  My problem with this tripod is that when a friend put it back in its case they unscrewed the steering handle completely which disengaged the washer and nut from the threads.  I'm not sure how to assemble it again because the housing doesn't seem to come apart and there is no apparent way to get pliers inside to hold the nut in place.  Not the product's fault - just a cautionary tale for other folks to NOT completely unscrew the handle!

I wanted a basic tripod for some quick shots unattended and thought to get this tripod as it was cheap and (based on other reviews) seemed to get the job done. It’s certainly no frills with a handful of interesting features.First off, it’s tall. At 60”, it’s no joke and really helps to get all the shots you need. Second, it’s easy to operate. The knobs make sense for what you want to do and the screwing/unscrewing part is easy to handle. Third, the carrying case is nice. Fourth, the built-in level helps you to get those nice, even shots. Fifth, the leg extensions are smooth and slide out very easily. The feet at the bottom are also movable (ball joints) based on the surface so that’s very nice.

I was thoroughly impressed with this tripod. It is light and allows for various angles using my DSLR or monocular. The adjustments are all plastic but they stay once set. The only thing is that it because it is light, you might want to weigh it down with something if you're in a place with wind [or even if not, you don't want someone to knock it over and have your expensive equipment come crashing into the ground]. There is a nice hook at the bottom for that, and you can hang your backpack there once you've set it up to its permanent position. Really great height too, once you've expanded all the legs. Nothing to complain, I don't see myself ever wanting to upgrade this tripod. This will do.

Tripod received appears to be adequate and should function sufficiently if handled with care.The Plastic used for this product seems hard, giving the impression it might snap easily at some point. Only time will tell.

Oh wow this tripod is amazing!!! I didn’t think much of an inexpensive tool to use for car pics, landscapes, monuments.  One of my favorite features is the feet that they will set flat in any condition. I also like that the mount for the camera is removable since I attached my holder to the mount and as a set they fit with the rest of the tripod in the bag. For those difficult because someone won’t move out of your pic, there’s the manual center pole that can go up almost 2 feet.So we field tested this in many different locations: asphalt, mud, muddy grass, trees, just feet from a buffalo, and the setup was in seconds!
Pros: Inexpensive, plenty of adjustments, built-in levels, good for basic useCons: On the heavier side, adjustments are not that smooth, can be wobbly

Very impressed with this tripod. Thick metal legs with extension locks and plastic turret mount that is easily adjusted and lockable in all 3 axes. Has robust plastic carrying handle affixed to one leg.Comes with an adequately sized zippered cloth carrying case.

it's a much needed step up if you purchase a cheaper telescope for star gazing or range spotter scope, usually a lot better than the plastic cheap ones those products come with. I bought  Celestron scope and this made it a bit more usable to gaze at the moon and definitely helps shooting at the desert or the range. The only downsize is the handle you hold onto and tighten to lock in place is all hard plastic and depending on the weight of the scope and angle it moves over short periods of time unless you really tighten it down which you must be careful not to break.. I wish it would have been of aluminum or steel to lock it but hey for $20 it's better than what i had prior and much more stable.

1) First of all, built like a tank for sturdiness but amazingly light.  2) love the two level indicators. 3) gear heads would love the flexibility and multuple adjustments designed into this tripod.  Hooks, handles, rotating hand turn raiser thing (hand crank) that bends out of the way when you store it.  The ease of the adjustment of the legs, the ability to crank the height reliably up to my eye site (I'm 6ft), to the ball bearing self adjusting feet.... and 4) lastly, it amazes me how small this collapses to in size.  You would never guess that this tall sturdy tripod fits into a small skinny bag that comes with it. Absolutely love it.  Best tripod I have ever had for both portability and ruggedness.  Great design.

I opened this outside my apartment and took it outside the box as I have been doing since this Covid-19 thing has been going on, then after making sure the box is empty I dispose of it outside, then I bring the tripod into my apartment and pull it our of the carrying case and realize that it does not have a mounting plate attached and so I reach inside the carrying case thinking it may be inside but instead I find a foot that is broken off!There was zero papers accompanying the thing, no little card explaining anything, nothing, no papers what so ever! In this time I am not going out to stand in a line and risk COVID-19 at a UPS or a USPS to send it back , so I have to eat the money and just be angry.

I've been looking for this god-forsaken tripod for the past 2 years! I owned one back in I believe 2014? and it was broken by a sibling a few years later, I replaced it with a pricier tripod back in 2016, only to find out the more expensive tripod did not have tilt capabilities... every good portrait needs a sense of DEPTH! it's been collecting dust in my trunk since the day I bought it because of that. Finally decided to search for "TILT TRIPOD" instead of just TRIPOD (I'm an idiot, I know) and found the exact one I had from before. I completely forgot the brand was AmazonBasics, which is probably why I couldn't find it when I was looking for it (I use my husband's account now, and I couldn't find this tripod in my old order history probably because I ordered it EONS ago). It's being delivered tomorrow and I'm SO excited! I really hope the quality hasn't waned over the years. I'll update this review if it has, but I'm betting on the quality of Amazon products, they have yet to fail me! Attached is a shameless selfie, using this incredibly versatile tripod!

Construction is better than expected for the price.  Nice aluminum legs, great functionality.But, I completely removed the handle (that swivels the camera up/down) once for packing, and it would not screw back in (I tried many a time).  So the unit sat broken/unusable for a few years.  Without the swivel, any placed camera would just fall over (up or down).

I needed stability for an event I was asked to take pics at and this had a really good price so I decided to try it out. It's lightweight but still fairly sturdy, and very easy to set up right out of the box. The only thing I would maybe watch out for is to make doubly sure your legs are completely stable because it's easy to set this up and have it be a little wobbly without extra caution. But that is fixable, just a matter of paying extra attention to how you're set up really. I can't speak to the longevity of this or how it would hold up to constant, everyday use but for now it seems to be decent for a casual photographer. For the price, it really can't be beat.

I have 17 of these for fireworks firing modules, and one I use for cameras. The largest camera I would put on this would be a DSLR with a kit lens, that’s its max capability. It’s great for holding an iPhone or iPad, consumer camcorder, point and shoot, and binoculars. It’s inexpensively constructed, not at all robust. I actually modified it to accept a ball head and here’s why. It has the spreader legs. I hate the tripods without them. And ALL the high end photo tripods don’t have spreader legs. If you want to move the tripod quickly, the spreader legs let you do that. Just pick it up and set it down and it’s deployed and secure. With the expensive tripods, and I have several, you have to redeploy all three legs and make sure they are fully spread out every time you move the tripod. PIA! However for heavier and expensive gear you must use these high end tripods, and I do. But for lighter gear this Amazon Basic 60” surely fills the bill. You must be careful nothing heavy is allowed to rest or fall on it in transport. It’s not tough enough for that. Let it be the LAST thing you load, so it goes on top.

I recently purchased my first DSLR and knew I needed a tripod. I picked this one up before heading out on a 7500 mile, month-long road trip. This tripod proved indispensable!First, my wife and I generally resort to unfavorable 'selfies' when we take trips. The tripod solved that issue! We stopped at each state sign we passed, quickly setup the tripod (which is a breeze), set the 10s timer and took our photo. We could do this whole process in just a minute or two it was so easy.

Everything works well, this is exactly what an inexpensive well designed tripod should be.  It has just enough leveling features that made it helpful for me when using with my laser level.  The quick clamps made it a easy to set-up perfectly in many different positions.  The only thing I didn’t like was there were two different locks that effected the pan.  The top of the legs has a locking mechanism for the height, and locking it on and off always rotated the column side to side.  On the very top is another lock to correct the issues. The workaround for me was to always get height first, then work on left to right.  That is not the best, but everything else about this was great.

This at first seemed like a good tripod.  It's easily adjustable, and the head allows for easy maneuvering of the spotting scope.  But it's just not rigid enough to dampen vibrations, so it doesn't hold the scope still enough for good viewing.  For the price, I guess I shouldn't have expected more.  But if you want a good tripod for viewing wildlife through a scope, pay more and get something more solid.

I like it. It works great with my Nikon Coolpix b500. Don't know about a DSLR though. What I do not like is it is not smooth at all when moving to right or left or up or down trying to find my birds. I use it for wildlife. So I'm sure it's easier to use with one's family or objects that co-operate, I bought it for times my yard is full of birds & my arm starts to shake. Forget it. I dont know it wD-40 would work.. haha. Seriously though, when you move the long handle it "over" turns. Maybe I'm just weak. But if I want it to move just a hair, it dont budge so I try to nudge it a tiny but harder and it moves over way too far!!! Its just not smooth. Maybe it's just me or just mine. I dont know. So it's been in the closet. Back to leaning elbow up against something again. It was a nice thought!

This is a great piece. While I have nothing to compare it to, it's very easy to use, even for a beginner like myself. It's got SO many levels and knobs on it, so you can always make sure you have a level shot. My only complaint is that it didn't come with any instructions, so using it was trial and error, although it's fairly straight forward. I'm not sure if none of them come with instructions or if it was just mine, but it would still be helpful, in the event that there are some features I'm missing out on. Can't beat the price, and it serves its purpose for me.

I do not recommend going cheap on this kind of item but if you rarely expect to use it, then it is a good enough buy for the price.A part of it broke and now there isnt a strong hold on the swivel part of the top so I can keep the camera at a certain point but if I touch it lightly it will move out of place. This break doesnt even make sense because I didnt do anything to deserve the break.

Purchased the 60-inch on sale when the price dropped to $23.49.The tripod itself is very lightweight and portable, even when fully extended.  The materials feel solid despite how light it is, and can take minor bumps comfortably.  It held position against moderate wind gusts at high elevations, and comes with a hook that you could attach an anchor to for added weight.  It also collapses quickly, and fits inside of a protective bag which is included.  The two bubble levels and swivel feet help you get the positioning you desire without wasting much time.  As with other tripods, it comes with a detachable mount and side grip.

Very light and strong. You can stick your camera on it and have it tightened down in under 10 seconds and be aiming your camera at something that probably won't sit still for you anyway. I like the bag it comes with. It is stronger than I thought it would be so not worried about it ripping anytime soon.Look, it really is made well. It looks nice. It comes with a bag. It's a strong bag. It is easy to use. It likes long walks on the beach and candlelight dinners. Your new stand might be shy at first but give it time to warm up to you. Either way I think you and your new stand will have a nice long life together.

Works great for the photographer with a crappy DSLR. As an amateur, it works well with what I need to do with it. In low lighting, it's nice to have when you set the shutter speed to low. I also use this for group photos along with a remote. For how much it costs, it's definitely the basics of basics. There's some small things that make it great, like the leveler. It bothers me when pictures aren't straight as an original and having to adjust it on the computer makes the quality lessen. Another great small thing they have is the quick clip. It attaches to your camera, and when you want to put it on the tripod, it only takes a mere second to attach. It also comes with a bag!I put it as 4 stars because the plastic bits are kind of fragile and cracked to the point where the rod-thing that adjusts the angle of the camera keeps falling off and the camera doesn't hold it's position as well.

The AmazonBasics 60-Inch Lightweight Tripod functions about as well as you could ask for an entry level tripod. Finding level is fairly easy and the tripod itself is light enough to bring with you when shooting. The mounting plate seems a bit easier to use than those on some other inexpensive tripods.The primary reason that it is getting a low score (2 stars as of 4/2018) is because there seem to be some quality control issues. The first tripod that was shipped to me broke on the second time that I took it out shooting. One of the plastic slips that secure latches for the legs snapped meaning that the leg would extend, but would not stay in place. So far, I haven't had the same issue on the replacement that was shipped to me, but I would be hesitant to recommend this tripod to others without letting them know about this first.

I bought this for my trip to Hawaii.1. It did not fit on my carry on so I had to have it on hand. The air carriers didn’t count it as my “back-pack” so I was able to have my regular carry on bag, backpack and had this as well.

I'm replacing a Promaster tripod that collapsed, and I needed a light weight inexpensive tripod quickly, so I ordered this one.  It arrived today well-packaged and in new condition - as I expected.  The price was right.  Now though I'm dissatisfied with the product ** it is a good deal  **.  For a beginner or someone who, like me needed a cheap tripod to replace a broken one this is a good tripod.Pros:

I must say, for $26 and change, you get two of these and the build is pretty nice for the money. It’s sturdy enough for intermediate use of a photographer or videographer that works inside. It had nice height to it, 5 feet total, in my opinion that’s perfectly fine for my needs. Has a nice plastic handle so you can carry with ease if you are going from location to location. You can adjust he legs easily with 2 height setting on the legs and the feet swivel cause they are on balls. And the bottom even comes with a hook, it’s nice for me cause I can hang it on the ceiling when I make drum videos.All in all, this is a fairly sturdy tripod for the money and it comes with a nice carrying bag. You can easily find sturdier ones but you can’t beat 2 of these for $26, takes care of all my photography needs.

I will start by saying that I am just starting to use my Nikon d3200. I needed a tripod to use while at my son's soccer games. I have this one a shot based off of reviews. I'm not sorry. The legs have 2 different extensions that adjust from 2.5 to 5.5 feet.  The knobs are all tight and secure, as well as the mounting clip. I feel that the weight is held very well and I don't worry about tipping. The only things I don't like about it, are the spacer bars on the legs feel very flimsy, and I can see them bending. I also wish that instead of one hook on the bottom there was a triple hook to hang various things from. Overall, it's been a great tripod for me so far!

Most of the tripod is solid and well made. I can extend it well, it's relatively tall, and handle is nice and it feels pretty sturdy for its mostly plastic frame.But i'm having trouble putting an actual heavy camera on the Tripod.

Amazon did a great job creating a quality product at a very fair cost! I am very happy with this purchase. Overall, all the materials seem solid and very easy to function and they threw in a free tripod case to boot!One thing to note is that this tripod uses a "cranking" function to raise or lower the camera from its base. It's the first time I've seen this and from what I can tell it's fine except that it's a little more time consuming from the traditional method and at times, when I put weight to the camera, the cranking function allows for some unwanted "sinking." Taking HDR photos, there's been a few times where it's caused me to have to retake photos due to movement or difference of perspective.
The tripod arrived VERY quickly, it is an amazign value for under 25 dollars.  This is a perfect intoductory tripodThe cons: a little wobbly if you use a larger lens/body set up

I was looking for a not-so-expensive and well-made tripod to hold my Canon EOS 60D for university courses. I browsed and browsed and came across this one by Amazon, initially skeptical because of low-price but still purchased due to good reviews. I've been using it for four months and it has yet to let me down!It holds my heavy camera four feet above the ground, the material is sturdy/tough, it comes with a balance bubble (I forget what it's actually called), and so long as you use some common sense you'll be able to set it up safely and quickly.

I ordered this tripod quite sceptical, previously I ordered another Amazon basics tripod, that broke. As soon as I opened the box, I was plessently surprised by the overall construction of the unit. From the (seemingly) anodized aluminum, to the overall construction of the plastic pieces, I was quite satisfied. The fact that it arrived in one piece, was surprising considering the lack of any sort of packaging material. Concidering the "emense care" in place from the local delivery people, that certainly aided my confidence in the construction. I didn't realize, until this point, that is had a crank to raise the camera. This super useful, it helps you smoothly pan the camera vertically for some exquisite b-roll. Oh right, the head. It's okay for the price. The plastic binds, making a smooth pan difficult. It has a level, which is useful for ensuring you don't have a sideways shot. But if you want that sideways shot, you can. When the screw is tight, the rotation adjustment has discrete steps, and if you loosen it, it becomes linear. The leg adjustment feel sturdy with little to no give, and the feet swivel to match the angle of the ground. For this price, I could not find another tripod with around same features. All in all this product has excellent bang for the buck, and should last.

Great quality. Durable. Fantastic Value.Now I'm new to the DSLR game. Got the camera and then realized I would need so many more accompanying accessories. SD cards, bags, lenses, etc. Not a cheap hobby. When I went to search for Tripods, I was surprised by how expensive some of them were. It's basically metal and plastic, why's it so bloody expensive?! Upset, I went to see what the cheaper options were. Now this part is IMPORTANT. If you're a noob like me this is crucial. The cheaper tripods, basically the 50 inch ones at the tier lower than this, are utter garbage. Read the reviews. They're slightly cheaper but basically guaranteed to break after a few uses. Those tend to be built using mainly weak plastic. Even Amazon's 50inch seems to just be a rebranded Chinese version that everyone makes. They all have basically identical product listings and terrible reviews for the most part. You've got a fairly expensive camera, you don't want that to break to pieces just to save a few bucks.

Lightweight, easy to use. I have never had any problems with my AmazonBasics Tri-Pod. It is very easy to use, comes with a travel bag, and is super lightweight. It comes with a hook if you need to ut a weight on it during windy days and it also has a level to get your photos or videos super straight. As it is 60 inches you can get really tall shots if need be. I have been using it for about a year now and I love it. It does everything a tri-pod is supposed to do without any of the extra fuss. Great for Travel!

This is a good, inexpensive tripod that works very well when the photographer is using the camera hands-on.  However, if you want to set up a shot and step away, the camera will droop if you have even a modest zoom lens attached.  The tripod cannot handle the torque on its own.  So if what you want is something that will help steady your picture, this will work well.  But if you want to use it with a heavy camera and/or zoom lens, I recommend purchasing a more substantial tripod.

this is a great inexpensive tripod. I was looking to spend $150-200 for a better tripod. I could not decide all the reviews had problems, so I decided to take a chance on this tripod until I decide what I really want in a tripod. So happy I bought this one. It has been great and just was I needed for now. If you need a tripod don't hesitate to buy this one, it is good enough for now and holds my spotting scope and my Nikon DX5000 with zoom.

I was in the market for a new tripod and just needed something to get me by until I could afford to spend a little bit of extra cash on a nice tripod. So I did a basic Amazon search for "tripos" and came across this one that seemed to fit the bill, and being me when it says comes with carrying case it only sweetens the deal!Notes:

The good news. It arrived today and it was much better quality than I expected for this price point. I just wanted something to use occasionally when on the road. This one looks like it will be pretty durable. Another thing is that it came with a very nice and well made carry/storage bag. Thick cloth and good zipper. That I hadn't hoped for.On another note, it's a bit more substantial than I expected. I was looking for something very 'slight' and light in weight. This is really nice but being better than I expected it's also a little bulkier than I expected. I ordered a cheap tripod to get a light one and ended up with a pretty substantial one instead. A good point if you were looking for that.

This is not a top quality fully, 360 degrees on 3 axis tripod, but it is basic, and will get the job done, It had good reviews. It is basically sturdy and the materials are good quality. It is not able to fully adjust the level of the camera. Hence a 1 star deduction. The big draw back is, you have to remove the mounting platform to screw the tripod to the camera. A rather stupid design. But for the price, it will hold the camera still But will still bend and twist when the shutter button is depressed. Good basic tripod for the money and is most likely much better than others in this price range.

Third times a charm! I received two broken tripods with nuts and pieces falling off, very frustrating. However, the tripod seemed to be a decent quality for the price with a year warranty, so I gave it one more chance. Finally on the third one, it was in a plastic bag and in perfect condition. I do really like it. Its my first tripod and seems to do the job well and has a ton of movement features. It just took so long to get it right, Im a little concerned about the longevity of the item.

2 perfectly placed level bubbles; perfect telescoping legs and clamps; perfect, bodacious hardware, cranks and knobs; generous, extra-long column for (yes, perfect) final crank height; perfect, beautiful metal finish; perfect, thoughtful, swivel feet pads (do not drag or bounce); perfect collapsible size and weight; remember not to over-crank (perfectly) designed knobs. Perfect!

Fabulous tripod.  I own an expensive, heavy, multiple function tripod, however I was going on a trip to Finland to try and photograph the Northern Lights and didn't want to hassle with my standard tripod.  Purchased this one looking for something light weight that I could take on the trip.  Didn't expect much due to the cost and was extremely, pleasantly surprised.  Great little, light weight, full size tripod.  Fit diagonally in my checked luggage and didn't put me over my baggage limits.  Strong and durable enough to hold my Nikon D7200 with a large lens without losing its position.  Highly recommend.

I liked this tripod, very lightweight and sleek looking. However, the one of the clasps that holds a leg in place was only held in by a very thin, cheap part that broke within 2 months. It still works, but the leg falls out and has to be mounted delicately.I didn't expect much, considering the price. Still, would have been nice to get more than just 2 months out of the thing.

I thought this would be a temporary tripod because my expensive, PRO tripod I use with my Nikon SLR broke. Nope, I am still using this nice and low priced tripod.Amazon has this great way of taking expensive items, like shredders or in this case the tripod, and calling it AmazonBasics. Well, they do a fine job at it. Yes, these are essential items and they are great!

I have two of these, and one has this problem more than the other. The connection between the tripod and central element is a bit loose and allows the central pole to shift around a bit. Also, the central column isn't perfectly steady when raised either, even when tightened down, so it wobbles a bit too.I didn't expect perfection for the price, but I have gotten significantly sturdier tripods at this same price, and the inconsistent build quality between the two Amazon Basics tripods suggests that there is room for improvement.

With the light weight, I didn't expect this tripod to be particularly stable, and it wasn't. The real disappoint is with the lack of smoothness when panning or changing elevation angle.  It sticks, then releases regardless of the friction setting on the adjustment knobs.  I've tried lubricating it, but I haven't been able to disassemble the head to do that properly.  Customer support was almost worthless, although after much research they recommend a lubricant (silicon).  Don't expect a manual or exploded view diagram (hey, at least they didn't laugh at me during either of my separate calls). It's a cheap POS, just don't expect anything else.  I like the light weight when I have to carry it walking or bicycling.

Just arrived today. For the price point, I doubt you would find a better tripod. It has 2 sets of cam locks on each leg for 2 separate height adjustments.  Then, there is a crank system to raise the center section.  I put 3 different devices on it to try it out.  With my lightweight point and shoot and my small digital camcorder, the only complaint I have is the initial jolt when panning. This jolt is less noticeable with a heavier slr type camera (about 22 ounces) but it's still there.  This issue may work itself out with more use but only time will tell.  Seems fairly stable in its highest position. High winds may change that.  Unless you're indoors or its calm out, I wouldn't recommend straying too far from the tripod if it's fully extended.As others have stated, the quick release has a tab on the bottom for tightening the mount to your device which is nice and convenient. I personally don't have a need for the hanging hook but I'm sure others do.  Carrying bag that comes with is typical fabric for something in this price point.

I am a photographer and I was surprised by this tripod.  It is very well made, has the necessary elements for adjustment, quick mount and great height.  For the price it really cannot be beat.  Would I use it on a professional shoot?  Probably never.  I will use it for vacationing and for the cell phone use.  It is light weight and easily will pack in a carry-on bag. It is sturdy enough to hold a 35mm SLR without swaying or tipping.  The plastic gears though do not warrant the trust for a $2K camera.

PROS: Gets the job done on the cheap if you’re doing photography. I like the quick detach mechanism, the grip, and the leveling bumble. Aluminum and plastic. A good deal for the price.CONS: If you at shooting video, Do not bother with these! If you intend to shoot video where you need to pan the shot to the sides, the swivel heads on these tripods are horrible because they produce chatter in the side to side motion. It is just not smooth. I got a horrible chatter / vibration in my video. Also, if you will be shooting around people, it’s so lightweight that a small touch can shake the whole stand. Not good for video.

This was my first tripod so I can’t compare to other more expensive ones. I’m an amateur photographer and this met my needs very well. Taking videos, selfies, group photos it’s been great so far. It is very easy to carry in its bag, it’s lightweight, very easy to adjust height/angles, extend legs and change positions. Stability is good too! Overall I am very satisfied with it for my purposes. If you are like me don’t hesitate to give this Amazon product a try.  I’m giving it 5 stars because for the price it met all my expectations with flying colors so far.

I love this tripod! It's an amazing price... Since it's so cheap, I really did not think it was going to be that good. But I've used it multiple times now, and it has worked amazingly every time. It has been very sturdy, extremely light weight, and it comes with a carrying case which really comes in handy. Plus, the height is really just perfect! I have multiple cameras and for the price, there really isn't a better tripod for the job. Especially if you're just starting out with photography or just need a basic tripod that will get the job done, then this is definitely the best option out there.

This lightweight travel tripod will never replace the heavy duty tripod that I own that can withstand the wind, etc.. But this little beauty had so many great reviews and even a recommendation from a photographer in the field that I had to check it out.  So light but still sturdy, very inexpensive, and a must when you travel remote in small planes where they limit your weight.  A must if you are on foot a lot and need that tripod for scenic or astrophotography.  A mirrorless camera like a Sony a6000 is what I use.  I gave it a four star on durability because I have yet put it through that use and do not know how it will hold up.  I know that I have to treat it with more respect than my big tripod.

This tripod is an incredible value for the price! I purchased this knowing I couldn't afford to buy a very fancy tripod, but needed something sturdy and high quality just the same. I am a student taking a photography class, and enjoy photography a great deal; so purchasing a tripod was a must for me. This tripod gives you all the flexibility you might need, with a quick release plate that allows you to go from tripod to handheld in seconds, as well as two different levels to help you gauge how tilted the tripod is, a special carrying case, and even a hook to place a weight on the bottom of the tripod for windy situations! I have been using this heavily for about 4 months now, and can honestly say I have no complaints.It does not feel too flimsy or shaky when I have my camera on it, and it is extremely easy to set up and fold up. There are joints on it that allow you to tilt your camera if you need to, as well as a handle for rotating the camera if you are taking panoramas, or video.
This is a pretty good basic tripod and is very lightweight an portable.It is not very expensive, and you get what you pay for...

This is JUST what I need. I actually received a broken one and amazon was quick to replace it for me. It has two levels of telescoping legs, the center shaft cranks up and down, and it has attachments at the top for horizontal and vertical pictures. You can secure in place with screw devices included.I just shot my own family pictures this week and tripod was super steady and secure. There is a hook at the base- I’m not sure exactly what it’s for, but I hang my camera bag on it for more weight to secure the tripod. I like the height, as once you get the camera on, it’s a perfect height for group shots. We had 15 in our group and the level was nice (you don’t want to take pics from a lower angle and accent the chins!!!!), slightly higher than I anticipated.

This is a great tripod. I am very satisfied with its ease of use and portability. I especially like that it seems very well made and not cheap generic like product. I have bought an inexpensive tripod in past that was a cheap walmart special but it was terrible. Was worthless. This however is wonderful. Im sure there are more expensive higher end products that are stronger heavier and just heavy duty for bulky super zoom lenses but this item is more than enough for me. It can easily support my canon dslr and lenses. Also the carry bag is very durable. All around great product. Its a bargain! I use this for Photography and video shoots.

Ordered this to use with my projector to watch movies on my deck.The initial connection between the tripod and projector was very unstable.  So, I made my own adapter using a wooden block, 1/4” nut, Velcro pads.  15 minute job.

I bought this to use with heavy binoculars, Celestron SkyMaster Giant 15x70 Binoculars with Tripod Adapter.  The adapter that came with the binoculars worked perfectly in this tripod.  I am thrilled with the lightweight of it and the ease of using it at various heights.  It comes with an easy to use carry case and even has a little hook on the tripod for the case when not in use.  It is easy to manipulate into different viewing angles  It did not come with instructions, so you have to figure out how to adjust the heights, but after a couple of minutes, it became obvious.  Well worth the money if using with a heavy device.

I'm just a mom who likes to take photos so I didn't need anything fancy but wanted a tripod on hand for those occasions when we want everyone in the picture. This is inexpensive, easy to use, folds up nicely and is super light weight. You could even just throw it in the bottom of your stroller to take with  you on various little excursions so you could ensure you always had a picture with the kids instead of always being behind the camera. I'm sure it would work well for professional photographers too. If you just need a tripod that's functional, this one will do the job.

I have a 70's tripod that is entirely metal parts, which continues to function well. However, it is heavier than the modern plastic & aluminum ones (like this product), so I thought to try out an Amazon Suggested product.Not that impressive since the key features of locking it into place fail to work within a year. The weak spots on the tripod are hard to overcome with glues, tape, adding new bolts, etc., because the design is not well tested for failure (evidently).

Previously I had ordered another version of the amazon essentials camera tri-pod and it was okay, but easily had broken. So I decided to give it another shot and ordered this one. So far I am very pleased and this one seems to be much sturdier without a huge weight difference from the one I previously had. So far zero complaints. It seems to work for my Nikon d3500 perfectly and also for my smaller canon as well as my phone. It doesn’t come with a phone attachment piece, but those are easily found for cheap and I already had one also. It it easily adjusted and folds up and down easily.

I bought this as a travel tripod. It's certainly light weight but it'a also very flimsy. Even with a 3 gallon water container hanging from the hook for stability it's pretty wobbly. The worst part is the head which is plastic to plastic and sticks terribly as you attempt to pan. With my Nikon D3200 + Tamron 1600 for long shots it's almost impossible to pan with enough smoothness to capture a moving object. It's also difficult to lock in an exact spot as the locking for up/down tends to move the camera as you rotate the lock. I'd buy something else. A lot of Amazon Basics stuff is good, but this it just awful. The picture shows it in use Aug 2019 at Speed Week on the Bonneville Salt Flats

Very light-weight and the plastic "locking" mechanisms do not seem like they will hold up under normal conditions ... time will tell but I suspect that this unit will have to go back to Amazon.  I could be wrong but these are my first impressions.The "Bubble-Level" is very hard to see.  If you need something "more reliable" ... this product may not be what you are looking for.  If you are going to set it up and leave it in one place ... maybe this will work for you.

Updated Review 2* May 2019: Not recommended for videography due to problematic horizontal pan.The first time I used the tripod it was a stationary setup. This time I needed to be able to pan.  Rotating the camera on its vertical axis was nice and smooth, however, rotating the camera along its horizontal axis from left to right was restricted/choppy even with the tightening knob fully disengaged. So much so that movement and video are choppy, and the whole tripod would move if not held securely.
